topic.title: Fluenta DITA Translation Add-on
topic.shortdesc: This topic describes how to translate DITA project using Fluenta directly from within Oxygen

section.title: Introduction
section.p: Fluenta is a tool designed to simplify the translation of DITA projects. It parses a DITA map, resolves the references to all topics and subtopics and prepares a unified XLIFF file that you can send to your Language Service Provider. The Fluenta DITA Translation Add-on allows you to manage the Fluenta translation workflow directly from within .

p.foreign: Install

section.title: Manual Installation
section.p:
To manually install the add-on, follow this procedure:
Go to Help Install new add-ons to open an add-on selection dialog box. Enter or paste https://www.oxygenxml.com/InstData/Addons/default/updateSite.xml in the Show add-ons from field or select it from the drop-down menu.
Select the Fluenta Dita Translation add-on and click Next.
Read the end-user license agreement. Then select the I accept all terms of the end-user license agreement option and click Finish.
Restart the application.
Result: A Fluentasubmenu appears in the DITA Maps Manager contextual menu.

section.title: Translation workflow
section.p:
A translation workflow based on Fluenta has the following steps:
Create a Fluenta project. A project contains metadata associated with a ditamap, for example the languages in which the project is translated. This is an one time action.
At various milestones, for example when a new version is released, you generate XLIFF files for each language you translate to.
You send the XLIFF file to the translation service provider.
Once the XLIFF returns from translation, you import the XLIFF file. A translated version of your map and topics will be generated at the selected location from the XLIFF file.

section.title: Creating a Fluenta project
section.p:
The first step is to create a Fluenta project.
Open the main ditamap in the DITA Maps Manager
Invoke the contextual menu and select Fluenta Create project... This action is visible only if there is no project detected for the opened ditamap.
In the dialog that appears, you need to provide a name for the project and the languages in which the project will be translated.

Result: A translation memory with the same name as the project will automatically be created. Also, only one project can be created for a ditamap file. Once created, you will be able to edit it to change certain information.

section.title: Generating XLIFF files
section.p:
When you are ready to send the project to translation, you can generate an XLIFF file like this:
Open the main ditamap in the DITA Maps Manager
Invoke the contextual menu and select Fluenta Generate XLIFF This action is visible only if there is a Fluenta project associated with the current ditamap and the XLIFF files will be generated for this project.
In the dialog that appears, select the output folder where to generate the XLIFF file(s) and the languages that you want to send to translation.
Use translation memory will use the translation memory associated with the project to recover translations for the segments not yet translated. Reuse ICE matches will compare current content with the content translated in the past and reuse all existing translations.
Result: An XLIFF file will be generated in the output folder for each selected language.

section.title: Importing XLIFF
section.p:
Once you receive a translated XLIFF from translation, you need generate a translated version of your project.
Open the main ditamap in the DITA Maps Manager
Invoke the contextual menu and select Fluenta Import XLIFF This action is visible only if there is a Fluenta project associated with the current ditamap and the XLIFF file will be imported for this project.
In the dialog that appears, browse for the XLIFF file:
Accept unapproved translations will use translations that are not marked as approved in the XLIFF file being imported. Update "{MemoryName}" translation memory will store in the project translations memory the imported translations.
Result: A translated version of the project content will be created in the indicated output folder. If your images are not in SVG format, you will have copy them to the newly generated project.

section.title: Editing a Fluenta project
section.p:
Sometimes after creating a project, certain information needs to be edited. The steps are similar to those for creating a new project:
Open the main ditamap in the DITA Maps Manager
Invoke the contextual menu and select Fluenta Edit project "{ProjectName}" This action is visible only if there is a Fluenta project associated with the current ditamap and this project will be edited.
In the dialog that appears, you need to replace the project information you want updated. It is not recommended to edit the name of a project or its source language because they may become inconsistent with the associated translation memory.

section.title: Managing translation memories
section.p:
A translation memory is a database that stores sentences, paragraphs or segments of text that have been translated before. The original language, sometimes referred to as the "source," and its translation, also referred to as the "target," are both included in each entry, or segment, in the translation memory.
Open the main ditamap in the DITA Maps Manager
Invoke the contextual menu and select Fluenta Manage translation memories...
In the dialog that appears, you will see a table with all the translation memories defined in Fluenta.
In this dialog, you can perform the following operations:
Create... - This action will open a dialog for creating a new translation memory.
Edit - This action will open a dialog for editing the selected translation memory from the translation memories table.
Delete... - Delete the selected translation memory. If a translation memory is associated with a project, it cannot be deleted.
Import TMX... - Populate the content of the translation memory with content from a specified import file.One or more files can be imported into a translation memory.
Export TMX... - Export the selected translation memory to TMX format to view its content and use at a latter time.
